title: How many U.S. adult and pediatric hospital admissions with confirmed COVID-19 cases will there be for the week starting 21 February 2021?
preds: Deaths ticked back up this week, which is the only thing preventing me from moving more confidently into the "fewer than 45K" bucket. We can see that "total hospitalized" continues to drop, which would imply that there must be less admissions, but given the specifics of the measurement for this question, there is still some room for the number to have actually risen this week and not a good way to know for sure until the numbers are published.
Downward trend appears to be holding for the week.

So much for the rate of decrease leveling off! It looks like the decrease remains rapidly dropping. As of yesterday, there were only 55K people *in* the hospital. It looks like the rate of decrease in hospitalizations has remained fairly high. The conservative 1% drop day-over-day I used in my last forecast would have put us below 45K and I feel even more comfortable now that that is probably a low number. So! Looking good for <45K this week.

Surprisingly the distributions of COVID hospitalizations and deaths behave fairly well from a distribution standpoint (fairly normal, fairly modal, fairly bell-shaped). This can be seen for large data sets from https://ourworldindata.org/covid-hospitalizations and https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/us-all-key-metrics. The peaks and valleys of these graphs are fairly symmetric, at least enough to be modeling beforehand, but not so perfect that modeling will give a completely accurate answer beforehand. (Much like stock markets). Modeling the data from healthdata.gov and the two above sources from Nov and Dec 2020 shows that the current period 21 - 28 Feb is most akin to the period from 4 Nov to 10 Nov 2020. When these Nov data for admissions over the 4-11 Nov periods are summed in the healthdata.gov spreadsheet, the result is 45,500 admissions approximately. However, the overall distribution of COVID cases seems to be falling slightly more rapidly than it rose in Nov at the current time (see first two sources for examples of the distribution falling off more rapidly than it rose). In aggregate this seems to imply that the total hospitalization rate will fall below 45,000 for this week with very high likelihood.

The hospitalizations are dropping sharply as immunizations increase but are still behind schedule (and promises).  More people have COVID and numbers are dropping sharply from very large holiday and January numbers.

As of the latest data (20 FEB), daily hospitalizations look like they have leveled off slightly, although the 7-day moving average is still looking at a ~2% decrease day over day. If that kept up this week, we'd be below 45K. Given that it looks like the decrease is slowing, though, 1% (or less?) seems to be a more likely number. If it were 1%, we'd get below 45K, but not by much.

Looks like the pace of decline might be slowing a bit, but still coming up with around 35k on the 28th. Currently at about 47k as of the 20th. Data and plot: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

Currently hospitalized: 58,222. 
Local report in NYC said there was an uptick (reported today) in cases for the first time since Feb 5. Have not seen anything similar for the rest of the country, only downward trend.

Total for week ending 2/20 was 47,278.  Question is whether there will be a superbowl bump.  We are on the cusp of seeing these cases if they exist.  There was a slight bump up in 7 day moving average of cases.

The number of case decrease++
Ourworldindata report 19,000 weekly new hospital admissions for COVID-19 in USA, on the latest data at the start of February

57k as of Feb. 14. If the recent pace continues I'm getting 32k weekly cases by the 28th. Assuming I'm doing this right it looks very likely to drop below 45k, even if the rate of decrease slows down. Data and plot: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

Updating with most current data, cao 14 FEB. Looks to me like the rate of infection is dropping even more rapidly. As of my last forecast, if the total 7-day infections dropped by about 1% per day, we'd have been at about 65K as of the 14th. According to the most recent data, however, we're at about 58K between 8 & 14 FEB. Instead of moving toward a steady 1% drop, we've begun to move back up...to between 2% and 3.8%, and closer to 3% most days (again, percent drop of 7-day totals per day).  Hospitalizations are falling in 42 states (many by >20% over a week ago today), staying the same in 6, and up in only 2, including AK, which has single digit numbers per day anyway...hardly enough to have a substantial effect. If we take these new numbers as our starting point and re-calibrate our forecast using a conservative 2% drop per day, we'd be below 45K. Seems like this is possible given the rate of decrease in infections and the steadily increasing vaccination rate. Even if we moved back toward the 1% rate, we'd be looking at a total of about 50K. I'm moving substantially to the left.

Hospitalisations usually lag about 2 weeks behind cases.  Can’t access the defined data set so going on pure gut feel and detailed analysis from @Redcayenne and @Harvey-the-Rabbit .  Splitting prediction between bin 1 and 2, keeping same prediction as before for now.
As hospital admission rates have been declining steadily for weeks, I shoot for Bin A and B.  Source: https://ourworldindata.org/covid-hospitalizations
Correcting previous mistake based on daily vs. weekly figures.

Looking at the time series from Healthdata.gov I see the week ending today at 57k.  Prior week was 69k which was down from 81k.  So decrease is around 12k a week, if it were linear I'd expect 44k the week ending the 21st, and 32k the week that resolution is based on.  But that would have hospitalizations ending completely in March, so that rate doesn't seem realistic.  I expect the downward trend to continue but the pace of decrease to slow due to additional exposure from Super Bowl parties and Valentine's Day.
Continued decline overall, at least going by the CovidTracking.com numbers (which may be slightly different from the spreadsheet numbers)

I generally agree with the thoughtful analysis by @Redcayenne .  However, I am a bit more pessimistic.  I will start with a Super Spreader analysis based on hospital admissions.  Comparing the 7 day hospital admissions total starting 2 weeks after a key event to the 7 day total before the event.  For Thanksgiving there was a 22.6% increase.  It was 8.1% for Christmas, but we were already pretty elevated then.  For New Years there was a decrease of  7.2%.  The 7 day total from 1/31 to 2/6 (pre Superbowl) was 70823.  The question resolution will be the 7 day total starting 2 weeks from the Superbowl.  If you buy into the super spreader theory - and assume the Superbowl was a superspreader event - then we would expect hospital admissions to be about what were just before the Superbowl if not higher.  I also think the new strains will have a bigger effect than most people think.  Everyone has gotten comfortable with the safety measures they have been taking.  But those won't be nearly as effective for the new strains.  In addition, it has been suggested that the new strains are more infectious because they deliver a higher viral load.   This could cause hospitalization to occur more quickly and lead to higher hospitalization rates https://nymag.com/intelligencer/article/what-is-the-new-covid-19-strain-that-shut-down-england-u-k.html.  So we might be a bit too comforted by the recent drop in cases and hospitalizations. I am optimistic about the long-term value of vaccines.  But in the short term I think their effects on hospital admissions will be limited, especially given the extreme variation in eligibility rules across states.  My guess is that those currently getting the vaccine are also the people who are best at social distancing. So I am starting with probabilities more in the 45-75k range, hoping I am wrong.

From 2/1 to 2/11 hospitalizations fell roughly 20%.    
https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/2-metrics-7-day-average-curves.  (I realize these are 7 day averages in this source. ) 
For another source for numbers go here:  https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations
Feb 1 = 93, 536.  Feb 11=74,225.  Decrease of 21%.  This source indicates that new reported cases fell by 25%, and California itself had a 48% drop!  It mentions that hospitalizations fell 15%.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-trends/u-s-covid-19-cases-and-hospitalizations-log-biggest-weekly-drops-since-pandemic-started-idUSKBN2A8286 Since hospitalizations are a laggard to new cases, I would presume that we will see continuing decreases in admissions in the coming week.  There are a few pressures being exerted on the opposite side however: 1.  Schools are reopening as urged by the Biden administration.  https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2021-02-12/us-schools-pressured-to-reopen-in-pandemic-to-get-new-cdc-guidance
European countries have kept their schools open by and large, and since Feb.1  and Feb. 11, their decrease in reported cases has been roughly 20%. https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/
However, the danger isn't in the grade schools, it is in the universities.  College students are more likely to get a full blown case, and many continue to enjoy social life believing they are impervious to the virus, and thus are a negative force on falling case rates.

2.  The hospitalization effects of the superspreader event (aka Super Bowl) will start to show up next weekend. (2/21)  That's a little late for this question, but there were parties all over this nation, and without a doubt there will be a bump in cases, with resultant hospitalizations 3.  2 new strains of the virus are on our shores - the UK version which by most counts is successfully avoided by those vaccinated individuals; and the South African version which can evade the antibodies produced by the vaccine.  Again - those effects will not be felt by 2/21, but something we should think about. That said - we are getting shots into arms much more quickly.  The USA has 14% of its population vaccinated.  https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations.  Obviously this has helped the hospitalization rate because the focus of the vaccines has been those most at risk of being exposed, (healthcare workers) and those most likely to be hospitalized and perish (the elderly) .  This has actually magnified the drop in hospitalizations because the administration of vaccine was so targeted to those likely to end up in a hospital.  Additionally, it is a sad fact that many of those most like to be hospitalized have already died. The virus made a job early on of wiping out nearly a whole age range of grandparents...   Given all of the above, I am thinking the drop in hospitalizations will continue, perhaps at a greater rate than the 20% we just saw because of more vaccinations.  Let's say it drops by 25% this next week.  That would put us at roughly 55,600 hospitalizations.  Remaining at a 20% rate of decrease would put us around 59,400.   Going heavy into the 45-60 range (because I don't think the negative pressures I mentioned above will be felt this early,) and doing some padding on the shoulders.  Something pushes me to think that the rate of decrease may start slowing down some, because by targeting who we did we picked the low hanging fruit.  Also, many places have hit difficulties with supply chains in the face of HUGE demand.  Thus I will probably pad more in the 60-75 range.

The number of case decrease++ Ourworldindata report 22,000 weekly new hospital admissions for COVID-19 in USA, on the latest data at the end of January : https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/weekly-hospital-admissions-covid?tab=chart&stackMode=absolute&time=2021-01-03..latest The Crowd is 23/64/12/1/0/0/0

Currently, daily new US cases are in the 90,000-100000 range, there's a slow decline daily but I don't think it will drop dramatically this week. From those cases, not all will be hospitalized of course. However, taking into account probable case increases from Superbowl gatherings, I would say the hospitalizations will be more than in previous weeks.
Cases declining. Exponential growth would suggest a more gradual decrease (not straight drop off) or cases. At 75k for current week.

Down to about 70k. I think there's a high chance it gets below 60k, but also I would guess the rate of decline won't hold at such a steep pace for long and will slow, making 45-60 the most likely. To get below 45 it would have to maintain the same steep pace through the month. Data and plot: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

I applied the slope of new coronavirus cases from another source to the hospital admissions data two weeks into the future. I am assuming COVID hospitalizations will lag case counts because individuals develop severe disease some time after developing symptoms. Because of loosening restrictions and pressure on schools to return to in-person, I think there is a higher likelihood that admissions will exceed the most likely range I selected than lower.

We had the Superbowl (home gatherings), schools and restaurants reopening in NYC in the same week. Similar trends around the country, some increase is expected despite vaccinations (now about a million new vaccinations a day).  Can't seem to access the data on the link provided but going by other sources, which should not be too far above, hospitalizations are decreasing by an average 2,500 daily for the past 5 days and are currently at 81,439 (Covidtrackingproject just to give an idea while DHS data is accessed). Seems that reduction in hospitalizations will continue for the next week until we see if there is any uptick from the Superbowl and restaurant and school openings in large cities)

According to the COVID Tracking Project, we hit a high of about 132K hospitalized on January 7th of this year. It's important to note that this is a slightly different metric than that which is being measured here, which is number of new admissions.  Using the drop in "currently hospitalized" as a proxy, though, which I think is fair given the fact that the two numbers ought to be positively correlated, we see that we've dropped to approx 80K in a month's time, or about 38%. Note that at least some of that drop likely has to do with the fact that a whole bunch of folks celebrated Christmas...less-than safely (hence the big bump), got admitted, and are now out. So I would expect that trend to flatten out, at least to some extent. Indeed, the data appears to show this. According to the data provided, the rolling 7-day total admissions has continued to drop over the last week, but at a steadily slower pace. 1-2 Feb showed a 3.3% drop, 2-3 a 2.6% drop, 3-4 was 2.2%, 4-5: 1.5%, 5-6, 1.4%, 6-7:1.1%, 7-8:1%. As of today, hospitalizations overall are falling in 38 states, remaining about the same in 12, and rising in only 1 (https://covidtracking.com/data/charts/14-day-change-hospitalized). This is not additive to the above note, but simply a further indication that the reduction in hospitalizations is not limited to a single region.  Also, it looks like our vaccination rate is fairly linear (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations), and has been for the last few weeks, so I would guess that whatever effect it has on our rate of hospitalizations is already seen in the data we have today. In other words, I don't expect it to alter the trend significantly in the next three weeks. Finally, I don't see anything that would dramatically alter behavior to the negative in the next three weeks. Although some states might choose to open up, it appears that the federal push is going to be more cautious than the previous administration.  So let's say everything equal, we settle on a rate of about 1% decrease per day on the 7-day total admissions. That would put us at about 56.7K on the closing day of this question. Toward the upper end of the second choice in the question. I feel fairly comfortable that with the vaccination rate steadily climbing, we'll be able to maintain our downward trend. 1% doesn't seem crazy. I don't see anything having a significantly positive or negative effect either way in the next three weeks. We may see a slight bump post-super bowl, but I don't see it having an enormous effect.

Unless the super bowl was a super spreader which I'm not thinking it was the numbers right now are total number of cases as of February 7th was a decrease from 105, 027 new cases to 87,889 new cases the 7-Day average 121,677

The Israeli experience has been that hospitalizations have been falling as people are getting vaccinated, so we should expect the trend to continue: https://github.com/hrossman/Patterns-of-covid-19-pandemic-dynamics-following-deployment-of-a-broad-national-immunization-program/blob/main/2021-02-03%20%20-%20Patterns%20of%20covid-19%20pandemic%20dynamics%20following%20deployment%20of%20a%20broad%20national%20immunization%20program.pdf I am a little less confident than the crowd in the speed of decline, because hospitalizations are a lagging indicator, and because the experience in Israel is that they have been surprised that the rate has not fallen more than it has. See for example https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2021/02/why-are-cases-rising-in-israel-the-most-vaccinated-country.html

Using the data provided in the question, the trend in last 20 days in adult hospitalization shows a decline in 7-day rolling number of admissions (not exactly the same for pediatric). Same 7-day rolling % shows a 2.14% reduction. Projecting this, we would be around 45K.
So, it seems clear that the number of admissions will be significantly lower than the ~ 80K at the end of January. Crowd majority predicts between 45K to 60K. What could impact this trend?
- Vaccination. US is strong in vaccination, ranking 3rd worldwide [2], but, based on lessons from the top country, Israel, we will have to wait some time until we see improvement in hospitalization [3]. No impact.
- Tests. A high % of tests performed improve early diagnosis and treatment, reducing the need of hospitalization. Some data shows that US as average is almost 94% test rate [4] and from other sources, only 7 States are lower 50% test rate [5] but catching up quickly. No impact.
- Weather. Forecasting weather is a completely different issue, but we an assume that it will not be different in February on average than January. No impact.
- Gatherings. Next and probably most important one will be the Superbolw, and the precedencts could be Thanksgiving and Xmas-Year end holidays. While admissions increased at that time, the trend didn't change significantly, if anything declining slightly. We can guess that there is more optimism but, if any, only small positive impact.
- Beds and ICU utilization. One can expect that the % of beds and icu utilization could have an impact in hospital admissions, so that only more severe cases are admitted when %s are high. Using same data [1] we might see some pattern as avg increase in hospitalization decreased when beds and icu utilization reached max in Nov and Dec, but a lot more analysis is needed to conclude that. Also it's interesting that 7-day rolling bed and icu is not changing much  when the same rolling of admissions is increasingly negative. Slight positive impact.
- Not familiar with the US health system, but a question could be if any Public Health Policy measure would have an impact in hospitalization. I could find a reference in the Biden-Harris plan to beat COVID19 [6] to "Ensure everyone — not just the wealthy and well-connected — in America receives the protection and care they deserve, and consumers are not price gouged as new drugs and therapies come to market". Even this might be good intentioned, it can take some time to really implement it. Slight positive impact.
- New variants of the virus. Probably only experience we have on this is coming from UK [7] and South Africa [8], and they are not encouraging, with very quick increases in cases between end of Dec - mid Jan. The curve is not that steep in the US [9], so it is uncertain if new variants are still to see or it was better managed than other countries. Mid increase.
- COVID policies. Arguably, most effective policy at the moment is lockdown, as UK experience seems to suggest [7]. There is a tension between health and economy [10] and good figures could relax measures that slow down improvement in hospitlization. Mid increase.
Too pessimistic. Let's see with the next set of data. [1] https://healthdata.gov/dataset/covid-19-reported-patient-impact-and-hospital-capacity-state-timeseries
[2] https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations
[3] https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2021/01/23/how-fast-can-vaccination-against-covid-19-make-a-difference
[4] https://www.statista.com/statistics/1104645/covid19-testing-rate-select-countries-worldwide/
[5] https://covidtracking.com/data/download
[6] https://www.whitehouse.gov/priorities/covid-19/
[7] https://covid19.who.int/region/euro/country/gb
[8] https://covid19.who.int/region/afro/country/za
[9] https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/us
[10] https://www.economist.com/united-states/2021/02/06/americas-two-largest-states-are-fighting-covid-19-differently

The rate of hospitalizations among the most vulnerable 65+ age group has dropped sharply from 63.5 per 100,000 in the week ending 09 Jan 2021 to 25.6 per 100,000 in the week ending 30 Jan 2021. The slope of the continued decline will likely decrease for the figure to end up at approximately 13 to15 per 100,000 for this age group and around 10 per 100,000 on average for all age groups combined.  Initial forecast: 33,000

If my look at the numbers is right it's at about 80,000 and dropping quickly at a pace of about 40,000 cases every 4 weeks or so. I don't know if that steep of a decline can maintain, so I think the floor on the 28th is going to be around 40,000, with somewhere between that and 60,000 as the likeliest range. I made a google sheet to use with the raw data. Feel free to copy to use yourself. I'll probably update this every week or so. If there are any errors please let me know. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZcBUiyKRnqhppa6yb2FFmRexYO6bOELvRCzMk7DZGd8/edit?usp=sharing

Linregs since the peak have been sharply downward, following trends since January for weekends and weekdays separately puts us at 33k for the week to be forecasted. You can imagine the decline softening but these curves don't tend to bend that dramatically. Admissions in 3 weeks reflect actions a couple weeks in advance, and there's little reason to predict a heavy upswing. The wildcard is the Superbowl obviously, but judging from how Christmas played out I don't expect it to be as huge as one might expect. The spike over the holidays displayed a clear continuation of a trend that started well before the holidays, with changes around individual holidays being almost non-existent. For that reason I don't factor it in very strongly, putting 45-60 at 18%.

01/21-01/27=89,139 (source: https://healthdata.gov/dataset/covid-19-reported-patient-impact-and-hospital-capacity-state-timeseries) The last weeks, Ourworldindata report 23,000-28,000 weekly new hospital admissions for COVID-19 in USA.  The number of case decrease

Similar infection rate to November, which seems to be the most recent data available, when there was on average 11,000 to 12,000 hospital admissions a day. The hospitalization rate may have decreased slightly as testing has expanding which allows for the identification of more mild cases which do not require someone to go to a hospital for treatment. Therefore, I will estimate the current hospital admissions per day is about 8,000-9,000 and that will stay roughly the same for the month of February so there will be 56,000 to 63,000 hospital admissions for the week of 21 February.
